newsitem.title: UK: British watchdog sees petrol review done by autumn.
newsitem.headline: British watchdog sees petrol review done by autumn.

text.p: The Director General of Fair Trading confirmed on Tuesday that a review of the wholesale and retail petrol markets in Britain was already underway and he will decide by this autumn whether further actions were necessary.

A spokesman for the Office of Fair Trading said earlier that it would soon launch a review of allegations that the ferociously competitive petrol market was driving independent retailers out of business.

"I expect our review to be completed by the autumn and I will then decide whether there are any issues which merit closer examination by the MMC (Monopolies and Mergers Commission) or whether some other remedy is necessary," John Bridgeman, Director General of Fair Trading, said in a statement.

The OFT was already committed to carrying out a review this year, following the previous one in 1993, and consultants have been hired to assist in the processing and analysis of data on the market, he said.

"We are examining the effects of changes in the market's structure since the MMC report of 1990," he said. "This will, of course, include the move of supermarkets into petrol retailing and the effect of this on other outlets."

A price war in the UK petrol market was sparked in early 1996 after Esso Petroleum, a unit of U.S. oil giant Exxon Corp, launched its Pricewatch campaign promising to match its lowest-priced competitors.

The growing presence of supermarkets, who sell petrol at the cheapest prices, and a downstream industry ripe with overcapacity also led to a near 10 percent reduction in the number of filling stations last year, industry analysts said.
A Parliamentary hearing last year explored whether motorists were enjoying unrealistically cheap petrol prices, which on average are the cheapest in Europe.
